channel.title: 10 push ups
channel.description:
I posted this on moparisthebest, figured it couldn't hurt to have it here too.
Well, I visit a parkour website pretty frequently, and they have a "10 pushup per post" challenge. Granted, that forum is full of more physically fit people, I figure it couldn't hurt to try to start it up here. What this challenge entails is doing 10 pushups for every post you make. Of course just pumping out a ton of pushups isn't really going to help anything, and the body will actually end up adapting to it and it won't be effective at all, so feel free to modify it to doing some pushups one week, sit ups the next, burpees, etc etc. The idea is just to get active.
Here's a link to a picture they put in their signature on the site:
[img]http://i1012.photobucket.com/albums/af242/A-SkyfiOriginal/10PostChM2105.png[/img]
Since moparisthebest doesn't allow images in sigs I just have a link to it in mine lol. I plan on following this challenge the best I can.
brb 10 pushups.

item.title: 10 push ups
item.dc:creator: @Faded.Fear Faded.Fear
item.description:
@Faded.Fear wrote:

[quote=“Scape-JAVA, post:167, topic:390589”][quote author=Faded.Fear link=topic=486498.msg4063648#msg4063648 date=1343669363]

Very nice. I assume you are going to make a career out of it?

Yes sir. I don’t see myself anywhere in the civilian world, except after 20 years and retired from the Army.
And then, I’ll just become a highly paid mercenary for the CIA or Government, whichever one I find the better contracts.

Yeah, the military has great benefits after retirement. Well, at least in Canada it does anyway :P.

Oh boy… the benefits while in the Military, and even when you’re out, are tremendous… It’s ridiculous tbh…
[/quote]

Ha, tell me about it. My grandpa retired from 33 years of service at 48 (Yes, he joined when he was 15 this was a loooong time ago), and he was getting like 5 grand each month just from the pension.[/quote]
Yeaahh buddy. And I plan on having 10+ years of SF Active Duty served.
My rank will be great and my retirement will be amazing + the mercenary jobs I’ll have = BANK.

LOL My curl… meant to say 125… -.-
And, no. Not BS.
Skype me bro?
I have the muscle mass to prove.
So next time you attempt being an arrogant prick.
Fuck off.
Kthx.

Read full topic

@abraham2119 wrote:

And I’ve never heard of ANYBODY curling 225 lbs with remotely decent form, not even olympia bodybuilders.

item.title: 10 push ups
item.dc:creator: @Faded.Fear Faded.Fear
item.description:
@Faded.Fear wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:161, topic:390589”]Heavy equipment operator? Not 100% sure what the actual title is, but he operates all of the bulldozers and whatnot.He was in Afghanistan about a year or so ago and all they did was build the bases. He said it was insane because they would be in the middle of the desert, with no electricity or telephones, yet while they were building the base people with their shops would show up out of nowhere. Before they were done it was like a small town.

They’ve been taking him to all of these different schools. Believe he just did airborne training or something for 2 weeks. He got some sort of badge during that training but decided to give it to someone else. He was one of the first picked to go to a school to rank up again, but he would have to enlist again, which he isn’t too keen on doing. He wants to see what they have to offer to keep him first.

If I would have any advice for you, is to do everything over the top. He said that the reason they love him so much is that he just tries and exceed their expectations. For example, they have an 1 hour and a half lunch break, but he shows up 30-45 mins early. Small things like that impress your higher ranking officers.[/quote]
Airborne Training, yea, he went through 3 weeks of intense cardio and crazy jumps for his wings. (badge you’re talking about.) Sounds like he’s a 21Echo. And, yea, I know exactly what you mean, I’ve been ahead of the game.
I met and discussed with a Captain of the United States Army last week, which is my recruiting station’s company commander, Captain Robles was her name, she’s been in the service 22 and half years. He had an interview between me and her, because I’m one of the best recruits the station has. Was pretty insane bro…

Read full topic

@the_wanderer wrote:

Heavy equipment operator? Not 100% sure what the actual title is, but he operates all of the bulldozers and whatnot.He was in Afghanistan about a year or so ago and all they did was build the bases. He said it was insane because they would be in the middle of the desert, with no electricity or telephones, yet while they were building the base people with their shops would show up out of nowhere. Before they were done it was like a small town.

They’ve been taking him to all of these different schools. Believe he just did airborne training or something for 2 weeks. He got some sort of badge during that training but decided to give it to someone else. He was one of the first picked to go to a school to rank up again, but he would have to enlist again, which he isn’t too keen on doing. He wants to see what they have to offer to keep him first.

If I would have any advice for you, is to do everything over the top. He said that the reason they love him so much is that he just tries and exceed their expectations. For example, they have an 1 hour and a half lunch break, but he shows up 30-45 mins early. Small things like that impress your higher ranking officers.

item.title: 10 push ups
item.dc:creator: @Faded.Fear Faded.Fear
item.description:
@Faded.Fear wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:159, topic:390589”][quote author=Faded.Fear link=topic=486498.msg4063541#msg4063541 date=1343660515]

I do an average of 400-800 pushups a day total

Sorry if I came across showing off, or being a douche or insulting anyone, I wasn’t.
Just stating facts.

no…you’re not, and if you are you’re over trainning.

Yes I do. And no I’m not.
I’ve been bodybuilding for a little over a year now.
I train with my recruiters and a SFO (Special Forces Operator) every now and then together, sometimes two or three, but there’s only 12 SFO’s in each unit. Meaning it’s hard for them to train with us.

You need to lose some before you start building muscle tbh, you have ‘fat muscle’. Yes, ik it’s a oxymoron.

Lol, bro. I’m in the cutting phase of my bodybuilding cycle atm.
I’m 195-200 atm, going to cut to 185, then build lean muscle back to 200.
My stats as of July 18, 2012:
Bench press: 325
Barbell curl: 225
Deadlift: 425
Squat: 375
2 minute situps: 87
2 minute pushups: 71
2 mile time: 15:57
5 mile march: 2:52:49
My last maxes, recorded by my recruiter. :3

I used to run 1 mile in like 11 minutes… I’ve gone a far ways bud.
I’m currently enlisted as a Future Soldier as 11X Infantry in the United States Army.
Can’t wait to ship, and when I’m 20, I’ll go through SF school.
I’m 18 at the moment.

PS: If you want, you can Skype me.
Just PM me.
I might be able to help anyone out that actually wants it.
[/quote]
o lolk[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: 10 push ups
item.dc:creator: @Faded.Fear Faded.Fear
item.description:
@Faded.Fear wrote:

The Wanderer:

There’s different special forces in the army, which is why I asked. Isn’t the Rangers a special force unit? My brother got his sapper tab about 3 months ago. I’m sure you’ll love it. I think this is his 4th year and he’s an E5 or E6; we are all proud of him. Probably not going to reenlist just because he is away from his children too much.

No, Ranger’s are not considered, “Special Forces.”

Army Rangers are Special Ops.

The only Special Forces team in the United States is the Green Berets. Special Forces= Green Berets (ONLY)

Special Ops…AKA…Special Operation Forces include:

Army: Delta Force, Army Rangers

Navy: SEALs, SWCCs, E.O.D. (Explosive Ordnance Disposal), Navy Divers

Air Force: Combat Controllers, E.O.D., Para-Rescue/Combat Rescue Officers, S.E.R.E. Specialists

Marine: Recon

Special Operation Forces do exactly as the title states. Each Special Operations Group has their own function/specialty.

Army Rangers and Navy SEALs are very familiar as they both special in fast, effective action such as taking a landing strip and securing it while a Combat Controller would call planes in for an air strike, or to fly in more troops. SEALs are more water oriented and Rangers are more land oriented, but they both can achieve the same goals.

If you are asking the big difference between Rangers and the Special Forces (Green Berets); The Special Forces are Force Multipliers. They specialize in going behind enemy lines for extended periods of time forming alliances and training locals to fight for the same cause. They train & sometimes supply locals for missions and help destroy the enemy from within.

To become a Ranger you first must enlist, then request Airborne training. All Rangers are Airborne trained and requesting this training is not necessary at this point, but it will aid in the process of becoming a Ranger. After you have completed the course, and received your “Wings”, you will need to ask your commanding officer for a recommendation into the Ranger program. Then you will begin your intensive physical, and education program which includes passing the S.E.R.E Program. (Survival, Evasion, Resistance & Escape) which is taught by a S.E.R.E. Specialist (Spec Ops). This training encompasses just exactly the acronym. You will learn to Survive in any environment with minimal supplies, evade the enemy when in danger of capture, Resist torture and interrogation, and escaping from the most hostile situations. During the S.E.R.E. program you will be accompanied by many other soldiers from different branches with different specialties including Naval Pilots, Combat Controllers, etc. Soon after completion you will begin intensive weapon training, navigation courses, foreign country education, etc.

Now for Green Berets. 95% of Green Berets were once a Special Operation Soldier and already have received the necessary training to put them a step above a normal soldier. You will again receive a refresher course on many things previously learn and undergo even more extensive physical punishment, education, and TREMENDOUS amount of political education.

Just in case you are curious. The best combat force in the Military would have to be the Anti-Terrorism Special Operations Group, Delta. Many Delta members were once previously Rangers>Green Berets and have now been hand picked for selection into this program. They are ONLY Anti-Terrorism unit and they are the cream of the crop as far as training, education, military tactics, politics, etc. They get the newest technology, the newest information, the most comprehensive training available. They are indeed the best, but again, they are targeting a different specialty in the military opposed to different Spec Ops.

In reality, there is no “Best”. They all have their purpose, they are all highly trained, very well educated, and very reliable.


Proud of your brother, that’s spectacular!
Crazy ass went through sapper school… Hahaha. xD
What’s his MOS if you don’t mind me asking?

Read full topic

item.title: 10 push ups
item.dc:creator: @Faded.Fear Faded.Fear
item.description:
@Faded.Fear wrote:

The Wanderer:

So are you going to try to become a green beret or do you mean just one of the special forces?

facepalm
Any SFO is a Green Beret. I’m going to be an Airborne Infantryman, then when I’m 20, in two years, while I’m in the Service, I’ll be able to go into SF school, once I pass it, I’ll be able to call myself a Green Beret.
More info: http://www.goarmy.com/soldier-life/being-a-soldier/ongoing-training/specialized-schools/special-forces-training.html

PS: I say 20, because that’s the minimum age to even be accepted into the SF training.
